review.title: Graph Regularized Low Rank Representation for Aerosol Optical Depth Retrieval
review.abstract: In this paper, we propose a novel data-driven regression model for aerosol optical depth (AOD) retrieval. First, we adopt a low rank representation (LRR) model to learn a powerful representation of the spectral response. Then, graph regularization is incorporated into the LRR model to capture the local structure information and the nonlinear property of the remote-sensing data. Since it is easy to acquire the rich satellite-retrieval results, we use them as a baseline to construct the graph. Finally, the learned feature representation is feeded into support vector machine (SVM) to retrieve AOD. Experiments are conducted on two widely used data sets acquired by different sensors, and the experimental results show that the proposed method can achieve superior performance compared to the physical models and other state-of-the-art empirical models.

metadata.title: Graph Regularized Low Rank Representation for Aerosol Optical Depth Retrieval

sections.heading: B. Optimization algorithm
sections.text: The objective function Eq. (2) of the diagram regularized LRR is non-convex, so the joint optimization of Z and E. As in [27] [28], we adopt the linearized alternative method of multipliers (ADMM) to optimize it. First, we convert (2) into the following equivalent problem: min Z, E, J, J, E, E, E, E, E, E, S, S, S, X, Z, Z, (5), which can be converted into the extended range multiplier (ALM).

sections.heading: A. Data Sets
sections.text: In fact, most of them will be able to play by the rules they have established in the past.

sections.heading: B. Experimental Setup
sections.text: In order to demonstrate the superiority of the proposed diagram, the regularized LRR model, the new representation, is fed into the subsequent SVM regression model. For simplicity, we call it GLRR + SVM, which is compared with the following six retrieval models: 1) the operational satellite retrieval algorithms by physical models; 2) the ordinary smallest square regression (OLS); 3) burr regression (RR); 4) NN; 5) SVM; 6) the classic LRR with SVM regressor (LRR + SVM). For NN, the optimal number of hidden nodes is selected from [2 · · · · 50] in increments of 5 via a 5-fold cross-validation. For SVM, we adopt the Gausskern core, as it usually achieves the best results in comparison with other cores (LRR + SVM). The optimal variance parameters γ for both Gausskern and Gausskern nucleus are selected from the 10 in the Gausskins and Gaussker core − 3 in comparison (LRR + SVM).

sections.heading: C. Results and Discussion
sections.text: For the MODIS dataset, the average RMSE values and the standard deviations to be achieved are in Fig. 2, where the smaller values correspond to the better performances. Several conclusions can be observed from this number. First, in Fig. 2 (b), one can see that the performance of the LRR + SVM is a little better than the physical model. Second, SVM performs best in the four regression models because it can solve the case with low numbers of training samples. 2 (b), the performance of the LRR + SVM is a little better than the SVM when the percentage of training samples is higher than 70%.

sections.heading: D. Parameter Analysis
sections.text: There are two important control parameters λ and β in the proposed method: the first is used to balance the effects of the low-level property and noise component, and the second is used to balance the information from the empirical model and the physical model. Figure 6 shows the 3-D diagram of the RMSE against it on MODIS and MISR datasets. Figure 6 (a) shows that the corresponding RMSE increases with increasing λ and β and then decreases, reaching the maximum value at λ = 1 and β = 10 − 1. Similar results can be seen in Figure 6 (b), and the maximum value appears when λ = β = 10.

sections.heading: IV. CONCLUSION
sections.text: Due to the observation that remote sensing data is often located in a low-level subspace, LRR was of course used to reveal the intrinsic data structure from corrupt or noisy observations. In order to obtain the nonlinear structure in remote sensing data, additional graph regulation was added to the LRR model. It is generally known that satellites currently in operation can generate AOD values through physical models. Therefore, the proposed graph model was constructed on the basis of such rich information. By conducting experiments with two sets of data collected from different instruments (MODIS and MISR), we compared the proposed method with the physical models and other state-of-the-art empirical models. Experimental results suggest that the learned representation can improve recovery performance.

AERONET is a global network of about 250 ground-based instruments that observe aerosols [31].
Most of these stations measure AOD in different spectral bands centered around the nominal wavelengths of 340, 380, 440, 670 nm, and others [32].
To facilitate inter-comparisons with other instruments, these data are interpolated to 550 nm using the quadratic fit on log-log scale from all wavelengths, at a particular location and time [2].
The detailed process can be found in [9].
We download 1045 collocated MISR and AERONET data from MAPSS [32], covering the whole 23 stations at all available time in China.
For NN, the optimal number of hidden nodes is chosen from [2, 50] in steps of 5 via a 5-fold cross validation.

metadata.abstractText: In this paper, we propose a novel data-driven regression model for aerosol optical depth (AOD) retrieval. First, we adopt a low rank representation (LRR) model to learn a powerful representation of the spectral response. Experiments are conducted on two widely used data sets acquired by different sensors, and the experimental results show that the proposed method can achieve superior performance compared to the physical models and other state-of-the-art empirical models.
